history.content: if you are considering 4 techs, I have to assume you very confident in your abilities (though having to ask is maybe not the best sign...).  Even then, note that you have three courses with labs: 106A, 128, and 7B- that is a huge guaranteed time sink, even if conceptually you can handle it.  So, I'd suggest dropping 7B (always prioritize eecs classes imo), and if you really want to take 4 techs, take something else with no lab and a light workload.

children.subject:
Depending on your EE and physics background, this could either be pretty easy or very hard. 128 and 106A are both pretty reasonable classes if you have a good background in dynamics/signals/linear algebra/are a proficient programmer, though the weekly 128 lab reports are quite time consuming (they're a good 2x as long as most other lab reports I've had to do).

If you have a strong background, you should be able to finish most of the labs for those two classes well within the three hour lab slots. However, I've seen students with weaker backgrounds spend 6-8 hours on individual labs for each course, so watch out.

As the other poster said, three lab classes is not recommended (I took 128, 106A, and another lab class at the same time. Even finishing almost every lab within its 3-hour period, it was still super time-consuming)

As far as 4 techs goes, that's not the worst 4-tech course-load you could take, but I agree that dropping 7B is likely a good idea if you're not sure.

history.content:
Hi,

I was hoping to get some opinions on the following workload for next semester:

1. EECS 106A (Intro to Robotic Manipulation)

2. EECS 126 (Probability and Random Processes)

3. EE C128 (Feedback Control Systems)

4. PHYSICS 7B
history.subject: Fall 2018 Workload?
